Creating Rpackages and using Rmarkdown Ben Williams Preface Materials for getting MESA into building R packages and using R markdown/bookdown. Ill populate this website as we go. An oft asked question is why make an R package, often this is followed with a statement of Im the only one who uses this code. There are many reasons for making R packages but a short list is: ease of use, we tend to reuse code, if it is easily available and documented it is more likely to be used and kept track of R packages are simple to create forces tidy code and workflow a great way to distribute data and code associated with a paper (or assessment) does not need to be distributed to anyone allows for easy exchange and reproducibility encourages (and provides space for) good documentation (works for data, not just code) Resources We will be relying heavily on R packages and bookdown.

2 What is a package? A package can exist in five different states. source bundled binary installed in-memory If you are creating a package or working on the code you are dealing with the source. Using install.packages() or devtools::install_github() moves a package from source, bundled, or binary states into the installed state (e.g., it is loaded on your computer). The library() function loads the package and makes it available for immediate use. Youve probably heard of a source tarball at that means is that many files have been reduced to one .tar and it was compressed .gz so you get the extension .tar.gz which is a bundled R package (just not in the way you are probably used to).
